examples.text: live animals
the number of **live births** *(= babies born alive)*
We saw a **real live** rattlesnake!
I need to talk to a live person *(= not a recording or computer)*.

definitions.definition: sent out while the event is actually happening, not recorded first and broadcast later

examples.text: a **live broadcast**
**live coverage** of the World Cup
You're looking at **live pictures** from a Las Vegas courtroom.
a live report from our correspondent in Jerusalem
on **live television/TV**
a live video feed
Is the **show live** or recorded?

definitions.definition: given or made when people are watching, not recorded

examples.text: The club has **live music** most nights.
the magic of a **live performance**
They're still one of the best live bands *(= best at performing)* around.
It was the first interview I'd done in front of a **live audience** *(= with people watching)*.

definitions.definition: made at a live performance, not in a recording studio

examples.text: a live recording made at Wembley Arena
the band’s new live album

definitions.definition: connected to a source of electrical power

examples.text: That terminal is live.

definitions.definition: still able to explode or light; ready for use

examples.text: live ammunition

definitions.definition: live coals are burning or are still hot and red
live yogurt still contains the bacteria needed to turn milk into yogurt
a live vaccine contains viruses or bacteria that are living

examples.text: the risks and benefits of live vaccines

definitions.definition: of interest or importance at the present time

examples.text: Pollution is still very much a live issue.

definitions.definition: functioning correctly, so that it is connected to another document or page on the internet

examples.text: Here are some live links to other aviation-related web pages.

definitions.definition: a person who is lively and full of energy
